text: [FOREST SOUNDS]
Welcome to the mountains of central Mexico.

This is the site of one of the greatest events
in all of nature.
The annual monarch butterfly migration.

Every year, tens of millions of monarch butterflies
fly to these mountains from all over the eastern
United States, as far away as Canada.

They come here to beat out the cold back home,
to basically chill, and while they're here

they're basically hibernating, living off
stored fat until the temperatures get a little

warmer, the days get a little longer, and
a signal inside their bodies tells them it's

time to return home, to start the next generation
who will continue this tradition.
Next year, and hopefully every year after.

It is one of the most amazing things I've
ever seen and you have got to check it out.
It's just down this path.
Let's go.
[Peaceful Forest Noises]
That was pretty awesome, wasn't it?
This amazing event, well, it's under threat.

It's under threat because of threats to this
place we are now, but also to the entire migration

path that takes these butterflies north and
south every year.

We all have to do our part to make sure they
have enough to eat, places to lay their eggs,
and a place to come back to.

Check out our other video on It's Okay To
Be Smart if you want to learn more about this

migration, and maybe even what you can do
to keep it going.
